guideline.name: Annotation of DPWG Guideline for phenytoin and HLA-B

relatedGenes.name: major histocompatibility complex, class I, B

gene.name: major histocompatibility complex, class I, B

recommendation.html: The guideline does not provide a recommendation for phenytoin in patients with no HLA-B*15:02 alleles or negative for the.HLA-B*15:02 test.

implications.html: The guideline does not provide a description of the impact of the absence of HLA-B*15:02 alleles on phenytoin.

recommendation.html:
• Carefully weigh the risk of SJS/TEN against the benefits
  • Avoid phenytoin if an alternative is possible
    • Carbamazepine carries a 10-fold higher risk of SJS/TEN for these patients and is therefore not an alternative.
    • A comparable risk has been reported for lamotrigine as for phenytoin. The same applies for oxcarbazepine, but the most severe forms (SJS/TEN overlap and TEN) are not observed with oxcarbazepine.
  • if it is not possible to avoid this medication, then advise the patient to report any skin rash immediately

implications.html: The life-threatening cutaneous side effect Stevens-Johnson syndrome/toxic epidermal necrolysis (SJS/TEN) occurs more frequently in patients with this genetic variation. The calculated risk of phenytoin-induced SJS/TEN in patients with HLA-B*1502 is 0.65%.
